It may be good for the town/city but it is not good for the coral reefs located around the city. Tourism in the form of diving and even snorkeling can cause damage to the coral reefs. It is unclear really how human divers (diving ) can cause damage to the coral reefs but one direct impact is from the pressure from boat propellers can cause strong, damaging currents. Divers can also damage coral by kicking, standing, bumping into, or touching coral heads, which can cause the coral to be unable to fight off disease and parasites.      Bleaching to make the coral reefs look better for tourist kill the coral reefs as well. It is one of the biggest things killing the coral reefs. The reason it is on of the biggest is because it occurs all over the world. Just about anywhere you find tourism and coral reefs. Bleaching is located or has occurred there at one time. Now there are rules and regulations on where, how much, and when you can bleach coral reefs. There are also BIG fines our there if you/campiness that are found of bleaching a spot they were not to.

properties.name: Conservation
properties.description: Many conservation efforts have been placed to save the coral reefs. The coral reefs are dying all over the world.  The governments have set up different conservation efforts. Some examples are the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA), Coral Reef Conservation Program (CRCP), Wildlife Conservation Society’s Coral Reef Conservation Program, and the Tropical Forest Conservation Act. That act was set up by the U.S. government, which has pledged almost $40 million ($39.45) to protect the biologically rich coral reefs.      "The U.S. is not the only country to put money and time into saving the coral reefs. Other countries have done the same and even countries that don’t have coral reefs around them still put money and time into saving them. Many people have spent the life trying to save coral reefs and many people still do. Some ways you can help save the coral reefs is by:• Stay Informed• Recycle• Don’t Pollute Our Oceans• Be Careful When Snorkeling/Diving• Support Conservation Groups/Start One Your Self• Speak Your Mind• Cut Down On Chemical UseThose are some was you an help save the coral reefs.

properties.name: Other Animals
properties.description: My first animal would be a worm. There are many different kinds of worms that live in the sea. The reef hosts a variety of worms, including both flatworms and polychaetes. Flatworms live in crevices in the reef. Polychaetes worms bore into coral reef skeletons. Theses worms make new area for more coral to form and place for different animals to live.     My second animal would be eels. They live in crevices in the coral reef. They venture out at night to hunt and feed. They have sharp teeth and a powerful jaw. Eels eat small fish, octopuse, shrimps, and crabs. They would be used to keep the fish population and other animal population down.

properties.name: Chameleon
properties.description: I chose the chameleon because It has certain characteristics and adaptations that allow it to live in the African Tropical rainforest. Chameleons vary greatly in size and body structure with a maximum total length varying form 1- 1.3 in. Three are approximately 160 species of chameleons. Chameleon species have in common their foot structure, eyes, lack of ears, and tongue. They eat mostly locusts, mantis, crickets, other insects, etc. They have been known to eat small birds and other lizards.The tongue allows them to get their pray in a fast manner- about 30 thousandths of a second. They have very good eyesight, letting them see small insects form a long distance. Most of them are arboreal (related to or resembling trees). Thy can change their color and blend into their surroundings, which allows them to be unseen.

properties.name: Sumatran Rhinoceros
properties.description: A mature rhino stands about 3.9-4.8 ft. high at the shoulder, has a body length of around 98 inches and weighs 1100-1760 pounds. It has two horns. The larger os the nasal horn. The posterior horn is much smaller. The horns are dark grey or black in color.   They have to spend a large part of their day in wallows. When mud holes are unavailable, the rhino will deepen puddles with its feet and horns. The wallowing behavior helps the rhino maintain its body temperature and protect its skin from ectoparasites and other insects.

properties.name: Sloth
properties.description: I chose the sloth because it has extraordinary adaptations to an arboreal browsing lifestyle. Slot fur exhibits specialized functions: the outer hair grows in a direction opposite from that of other mammals. Sloths have short, flat heads. They also have big yes and a short snout, long legs and tiny ears. They have stubby tails as well, usually 6-7 cm long. Altogether, sloths’ bodies usually are anywhere between 50 and 60 cm long.Leaves are a main food source provide very little energy or nutrition and do not digest easily. Sloths have very large, specialized, slow acting stomachs with multiple compartments. Symbiotic bacteria break down the tough leaves. Close to two- thirds of a well-fed sloth’s body-weight can consist of the content of its stomach. The digestive process can take a moth or more to complete. Sloths must deal with this be a range of economy measure; they have very low metabolic rates and maintain low body temperatures when active and still lower temperature when resting. They are usually unable to survive outside the tropical rainforests.

properties.name: Galago (Bush Baby)
properties.description: Their fur is soft, dense and wooly, coloration varying ranging from gray to brown. They have very large eyes. They also have large ears with four transverse ridges and can be independently and simultaneously bent back and wrinkled downward from the tips.   They are great leapers and run swiftly along branches. Their eyes give them good nigh vision, strong hind legs, acute hearing, and long tails that help them balance.

properties.name: Toco Toucan
properties.description: They have a striking plumage with a mainly black body, a white throat, chest and uppertail-coverts, and red undertail-coverts.   The long bill is useful for reaching things out-of-reach. It is also used to skin fruit and scare off predators. In flight, they alternate between a burst of rapid flaps with the relatively short, rounded wings and gliding.

properties.name: Kigelia
properties.description: It can be as thick as 6 mm on a 15-cm branch. The wood is pale brown or yellowish, undifferentiated and not prone to cracking. The leaves are orange to reddish or purplish green.The tree is evergreen where rainfall occurs throughout the year, but deciduous where there is a long dry season. The long leaves allow it to hang down into the air.  It gives off a scent that allows it to be pollinated by birds and insects.

properties.name: The Neem
properties.description: The Neem is a fast-growing tree that can reach a height of about 50-65 feet to 115-131 feet. It is an evergreen tree. The branches are wide spread. The fairly dense crown is roundish or oval and may reach the diameter of 15-20 meters in old, free-standing specimens. The trunk is short and straight and may reach a diameter about 4 feet. The bark is hard, fissured or scaly, and whitish-grey to reddish-brown. The sapwood is greyish-white and the heartwood reddish when first exposed to the air becoming reddish-brown after exposure.The neem tree can mostly noted for its drought resistance. Normally it thrives in areas with sub-arid to sub-humid conditions. It can grow in regions with an annual rainfall below 400 mm, but in such cases it depends largely on ground water levels. Neem can grow in many different types of soil, but it thrives best on well-drained soils. The leaves are mostly eaten by insects and the inside may be inhabited by them as well.

properties.name: Spondias mombin
properties.description: This species is a flowering plant with many leaves. Te edible has thin leathery skin. The leaves are very long, just like the entire plant.   It adapts to its surroundings by greatly multiplying itself. The flowers also greatly multiply. It has been naturalized because of its multiplying.

properties.name: Mucuna pruriens
properties.description: The plant is an annual, climbing shrub with long vines that can reach over 15 m in length. When the plant is young, it is completely covered with fuzzy hairs. When it gets older, it is almost completely free of hairs.It adapts to its surroundings by losing all of its hair. It is covered with flowers at certain times. It will also shed its flowers to adapt to its surroundings.

properties.name: Catharanthus roseus (“Rose Periwinkle”)
properties.description: It is an evergreen subshrub or herbaceous plant growing up to 1 m tall. The leaves are, 2.5–9 cm, glossy green and hairless. They are arranged in opposite pairs. The flowers are white to dark pink with a darker red center. The fruit is a pair of follicles 2–4 cm long.It can stand dry and nutritionally deficient conditions, popular in subtropical gardens where temperatures never fall below 5 °C to 7 °C.  and as a warm-season bedding plant in temperate gardens. It also can stand a long flowering period, throughout the year in different conditions. It is mostly eaten by small bugs and caterpillars.

properties.name: Landforms
properties.description: There aren’t too many landforms here in this biome. A majority of them are trees stretched everywhere throughout the African tropical rainforest. There are a few mountains, but not too many. There are some hills though. There is also a series of rugged hills that overlook and flat bottomed valleys, but covered in trees as well.

properties.name: Human Uses
properties.description: They currently support only small human populations. Food resources within the forest are extremely dispersed due to the high biological diversity and what food does exist is largely restricted to the canopy and requires considerable energy to obtain. The soils are often thin and leached of many minerals, and the heavy rainfall can quickly leach nutrients from rainforest plots cleared for cultivation. Cultivated foods and spices are a big use. Coffee is a big resource. Sugar cane has originally come from these tropical rainforests. Pharmaceutical and biodiversity resources are also among the human uses. These rainforests are called "the world's largest pharmacy" because of the large amount of natural medicines discovered here.

properties.name: Agriculture
properties.description: Around 60% of African workers are employed by the agriculture. About three-fifths of African farmers are subsistence farmers. Subsistence farmers provide a source of food and relatively small income for the family, but generally fail to produce enough to make re-investment possible. Some farms tend to grow cash crops such as coffee, cotton, cocoa, and rubber here and nearby.

properties.name: Tourist Attractions
properties.description: Currently one of the largest economic values here comes in the from of tourism. People travel both nationally and internationally to experience these rainforests firsthand. The economic benefits of tourism are the most promising way in which rainforests may be preserved. Hikes, climbing through the canopies, biking, and animal/insect watching are all common forms of attractions done here. This biome is not really a home of any cities. It is all just rainforest.

properties.name: Background
properties.description: These are tropical moist forests of semi-deciduous varieties. Some humans inhabit this biome. Many of its resources are overused. Deforestation is common here, which is a major contribution to habitat loss of the animals. This biome has the most important plant resources in all of the world. Most of all of the undiscovered animal species in the world live here.

properties.name: Climate
properties.description: It is very humid here. A lot of rain that falls mostly never reaches the ground. It stays on the trees and acts as a shield. These trees form a canopy. The reainforest floor is called the understory. This canopy keeps sunlight from reaching the plants. The annual precipitation is greater than 150 cm. The average temperature is around 75 degrees Fahrenheit. These rainforests usually never drop below 60 degrees.

properties.name: Conservation
properties.description: Governments have planned several ways to promote conservation here. The government has introduced forest protection regulatory measures by classification of some forest area, licensing requirements, and the apprehension and prosecution of offenders. Conservation is a big issue here, mainly because of these rainforests disappearing every minute by deforestation and other problems.

properties.name: Keystone Species - Chimpanzee
properties.description: Most can weigh as much as 160 pounds. They are around 94% close to humans. They walk on their two legs, unlike other animals. They usually make a pant-hoot noise when excited.Chimps are important seed dispersers, and their presence is a strong indicator of the overall health of the rainforest environment. If such a large species disappears, there will be a significant impact on the remaining plants and animals.

properties.name: African Forest Elephant
properties.description: It has a long, narrow mandible (inferior maxillary bone or jawbone - forms the lower jaw and holds the lower teeth in place. It has rounded ears and straighter and downward tusks. The male rarely exceeds 8 feet in height. The African Forest Elephant normally has 5 toenails on the frontfoot and 4 on the hindfoot. They survive on a diet of herbs and trees or leaves and large amounts of water.A major contribution to their endangerment is poaching. The pink ivory is highly prized by poachers and very valuable. They can be very difficult to catch in the cover of the rainforest. Logging is another threat as well.

properties.name: Golden Lion Tamarin
properties.description: This animal is reddish orange to golden brown in color. Its hair is dark around the face, which forms a mane on top of the head and on the cheeks and throat. Its limb are slender but capable with sharp claws. They are strictly arboreal. They are omnivores and mostly rely on rainwater, insects and other small animals inhabiting the bark of trees. They also eat fruit.   This species was first listed as endangered in 1982, rising to critically endangered in 1996. Deforestation is a big influence to their endangerment. The deforestation causes habitat loss for them, mainly because they are arboreal. There is an estimated wild population of around 1,000 individuals and a captive population at around 490 individuals.
